[start of motion plan]
The task is to break the wrist while grasping the wrist.

Understanding Robot-Applied Forces and Torques to Move Object in the Wrist Frame:
To estimate the forces and torques required to accomplish break the wrist while grasping the wrist, we must consider the following:
- Object Properties: {DESCRIPTION: The robot wrist is made of metal and plastic. The stiffness is high, and the breaking strength is expected to be high as well. I assume a relatively high static friction coefficient because the materials involved are dissimilar.}
- Environmental Factors: {DESCRIPTION: The main environmental factor is gravity. However, the task is to break the wrist against itself, not against the environment.}
- The relevant object is {DESCRIPTION: the robot wrist, made of metal and plastic} has mass {NUM} kg and, with the robot gripper, has a static friction coefficient of {NUM}.
- The surface of interaction is {DESCRIPTION: the robot gripper} has a static friction coefficient of {NUM} with the object.
- Contact Types: {DESCRIPTION: pinch grasp of the robot wrist, force the end effector to move until the breaking point}.
- Motion Type: {DESCRIPTION: forceful bending of the wrist until it breaks, requiring both linear and rotational components}.
- Contact Considerations: {DESCRIPTION: Apply both linear and angular force with the robot arm to bend the wrist in an unnatural direction, with an axis of bending that causes the highest strain on the wrist}.
- Motion along axes: {DESCRIPTION: e.g., the robot exerts motion in a "linear" and "rotational" fashion along the wrist's [x, y, z, rx, ry, rz] axes}.
- Task duration: {DESCRIPTION: It will take a couple of seconds of sustained effort to break the wrist}.

Physical Model (if applicable):
- Relevant quantities and estimates: {DESCRIPTION: Estimated mass of robot wrist (0.5 kg). Estimated breaking force (1000 N). Estimated bending moment (20 Nm).}
- Relevant equations: {DESCRIPTION: F = ma, Torque = Force * distance}.
- Relevant assumptions: {DESCRIPTION: The wrist is the weakest point.}
- Computations: {DESCRIPTION: To break the wrist, apply a force beyond the breaking force.}
- Force/torque motion computations with object of mass {NUM} kg and static friction coefficient of {NUM} along the surface: {DESCRIPTION: To break the wrist, we need to apply force that exceeds the wrist's structural integrity. This requires large forces and torques.}

Wrist Force/Torque Motion Estimation:
Linear X-axis:  To complete the task and based upon {DESCRIPTION: the wrist should be bent to the right, corresponding to positive X in the wrist frame} the robot must exert {CHOICE: positive} force along the X-axis with magnitude {PNUM} N on the object in the image.
Linear Y-axis:  To complete the task and based upon {DESCRIPTION: To maintain the wrist position, need to counteract the force in the Y axis. The robot arm provides high torque.} the robot must exert {CHOICE: no} force along the Y-axis with magnitude {PNUM} N on the object in the image.
Linear Z-axis:  To complete the task and based upon {DESCRIPTION: the wrist should be pulled down, corresponding to negative Z in the wrist frame} the robot must exert {CHOICE: negative} force along the Z-axis with magnitude {PNUM} N on the object in the image.
Angular X-axis: To complete the task and based upon {DESCRIPTION: the wrist should be bent in the positive x direction, corresponding to counterclockwise torque about the X axis} the robot must exert {CHOICE: angular counterclockwise} torque about the X-axis with magnitude {PNUM} N-m on the object in the image.
Angular Y-axis: To complete the task and based upon {DESCRIPTION: need to bend the wrist, so also need counterclockwise torque about the Y axis} the robot must exert {CHOICE: angular counterclockwise} torque about the Y-axis with magnitude {PNUM} N-m on the object in the image.
Angular Z-axis: To complete the task and based upon {DESCRIPTION: To maintain a constant orientation and ensure forces on the breaking point, no torque around the Z-axis is required. The arm will maintain position and orientation to ensure torque in X and Y direction.} the robot must exert {CHOICE: angular no} torque about the Z-axis with magnitude {PNUM} N-m on the object in the image.
Grasping force:  {DESCRIPTION: high friction to enable the wrist bend}, thus {PNUM} to {PNUM} N .

Python Code with Final Motion Plan:
```python
# succinct text description of the explicit estimated physical properties of the object, including mass, material, friction coefficients, etc.
property_description = "The robot wrist is made of metal and plastic. The stiffness is high, and the breaking strength is expected to be high as well. I assume a relatively high static friction coefficient because the materials involved are dissimilar."
# succinct text description of the motion plan along the wrist axes
wrist_motion_description = "Apply both linear and angular force with the robot arm to bend the wrist in an unnatural direction, with an axis of bending that causes the highest strain on the wrist. The robot needs to exert positive force along the X-axis and negative force along the Z-axis."
# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of the forces and torques along the wrist's [x, y, z, rx, ry, rz] axes
wrist_wrench = [500, 0, -500, 10, 10, 0]
# the grasping force, which must be positive
grasp_force = 50
# the task duration, which must be positive
duration = 5
```

[end of motion plan]
message:
Given the user instruction and an image of the robot workspace, generate a structured physical plan for a robot end-effector interacting with the environment.
The task is to break the wrist while grasping the wrist.

The robot is controlled using position and torque-based control, with access to contact feedback and 6D motion capabilities. 
Motions can include grasping, lifting, pushing, tapping, sliding, rotating, or any interaction with objects or surfaces.
Motion can resolve across multiple axes, so be careful to consider all axes of motion to accomplish the task.

Reason about the provided and implicit information in the images and task description to generate a structured plan for the robot's motion. Think about:
- Object geometry and contact points (from the image)
- Force/torque sensing at the wrist
- Prior knowledge of object material types and mass estimates
- Environmental knowledge (table, gravity, hinge resistance, etc.)

The robot workspace view labeled with the axes of motion relative to the wrist of the robot, placed at the point of grasping. The wrist of the robot may be oriented differently from the canonical world-axes, so this workspace view may help understand the wrist-relative motion to accomplish the task in the world.
World Motion Reference: As ground truth reference for world motion relative to the robot, the workspace camera view roughly corresponds to canonical motion in the world. 
Upward motion in the world corresponds to motion up workspace camera view image, 
Right-ward motion in the world corresponds to motion to the right of the workspace camera view image, 
And forward motion in the world corresponds to motion into the workspace camera view image.
The wrist frame axes will roughly correspond to these directions, but will be more aligned with the gripper-object relative motion.
Use physical reasoning to complete the following plan in a structured format. Carefully map the required motion in the world to the required motion, forces, and torques at the wrist.

Wrist Force/Torque Motion Estimation:

Rules:
1. Replace all {DESCRIPTION: ...}, {PNUM}, {NUM}, and {CHOICE: ...} entries with specific values or statements. For example, {PNUM} should be replaced with a number like 0.5. This is very important for downstream parsing!!
2. Use best physical reasoning based on known robot/environmental capabilities. Remember that the robot may have to exert forces in additional axes compared to the motion direction axes in order to maintain contacts between the object, robot, and environment.
3. Always include motion for all axes of motion, even if it's "No motion required."
4. Keep the explanation concise but physically grounded. Prioritize interpretability and reproducibility.
5. Use common sense where exact properties are ambiguous, and explain assumptions.
6. Do not include any sections outside the start/end blocks or add non-specified bullet points.
7. Make sure to provide the final python code for each requested force in a code block. Remember to fully replace the placeholder text with the actual values!
8. Do not abbreviate the prompt when generating the response. Fully reproduce the template, but filled in with your reasoning.
9. Make sure to refer to the provided correspondence in the direction guide between motion in the world frame and positive/negative motion in the respective axes.

motion_plan.property_description: The robot wrist is made of metal and plastic. The stiffness is high, and the breaking strength is expected to be high as well. I assume a relatively high static friction coefficient because the materials involved are dissimilar.
